entry.title: Markdown
entry.content:
Markdown Cheat Sheet

Thanks for visiting The Markdown Guide!

This Markdown cheat sheet provides a quick overview of all the Markdown syntax elements. It canâ€™t cover every edge case, so if you need more information about any of these elements, refer to the reference guides for basic syntax and extended syntax.

Basic Syntax

These are the elements outlined in John Gruberâ€™s original design document. All Markdown applications support these elements.

Heading

H1

H2

H3

Bold

bold text

Italic

italicized text

Blockquote

blockquote

Ordered List

  1. First item
  2. Second item
  3. Third item

Unordered List

  • First item
  • Second item
  • Third item

Code

code

Horizontal Rule

Link

Markdown Guide

Image

Extended Syntax

These elements extend the basic syntax by adding additional features. Not all Markdown applications support these elements.

Table

Syntax Description
Header Title
Paragraph Text

Fenced Code Block

Footnote

Hereâ€™s a sentence with a footnote. [^1]

[^1]: This is the footnote.

Heading ID

My Great Heading

entry.title: Orientation
entry.content:
Orientation

Today is my Orientation day. Since Covid-19 pandemic, I've been waiting two years for commencing. Urvi Parikh is the orientation speecher who told us a lot of information about course and outcome in the future. I found out my classmate only one person. At least, I can start the course finally.

The picture above is my textbook, that scared me a lot. It's really thick one, it looks like it can kill someone.

entry.title: Load of Aussi
entry.content:
Aussi Expressions

  1. Are you kidding?
  2. As if!
  3. Thatâ€™s epic!
  4. No worries!
  5. Tough luck
  6. Catch ya(later)
  7. Sorry
  8. Whatâ€™s going on?
  9. Chugging along
  10. Iâ€™m wrecked
  11. Iâ€™m going to bail

1. Are you kidding?

Are you joking?
Are you serious?
For real?
Fair dinkum? (Slang)

2. As if!

To show disbelief, to show that you donâ€™t belief something is true, that you doubt something.

  • As if that would be the case
  • As if that is true

EX: As if I donâ€™t like chocolate. (å¥½åƒæˆ‘ä¸å–œæ­¡å·§å…‹åŠ›ä¸€æ¨£)

3. Thatâ€™s epic!

To show shock and superise that something is awesome, something is incredible.

  • Thatâ€™s awesome
  • That rocks
  • Thatâ€™s great
  • Thatâ€™s phenomenal
  • Thatâ€™s incredible

4. No worries!

  • Not to worry
  • Not a problem
  • All good
  • Thereâ€™s no issued
  • No wukkas (No fucking worries)(Slang)

5. Tough luck

  • Too bad
  • Deal with it
  • I donâ€™t care
  • What a shame

6. Catch ya(later)

  • Goodbye
  • See you later
  • See ya

7. Sorry

  • Pardon?
  • What did you say?
  • Could you please repeat that?

8. Whatâ€™s going on?

Whatâ€™s happening? Whatâ€™s your news? [^tip]

[^tip]: When we replay to greeting that start with â€œwhatâ€, the response is generally a negated response. ex: not much, not a lot, nothing.

  • Whatâ€™s going on with you?
  • Whatâ€™s going on in your life?
  • Whatâ€™s happening?
  • How have you been up to?
  • Sâ€™going on? (Slang)

9. Chugging along

Uesd to replay to the greeting, like â€œHow are you?â€, â€œHow are you going?â€, â€œHow are you doing?â€

It kind of like Iâ€™m continuing to do something in the same way as before.

10. Iâ€™m wrecked (Slang)

  • Iâ€™m stuffed
  • Iâ€™m cactus
  • Iâ€™m buggered
  • Iâ€™m fatigued
  • Iâ€™m tired

11. Iâ€™m going to bail

To bail means â€œto leaveâ€

  • Iâ€™m going to leave
  • Iâ€™mena bail (Slang)

entry.title: ã€PTEã€‘Summarize Spoken Text
entry.content:
PTE å­¸ç¿’ç­†è¨˜ - SST

Facts

  • Number: 2-3 tasks
  • Word Length: 50-70 words
  • Time: 10 minutes each
  • Scoring: Writing and Listening

Scoring

  • Content (0-2)
  • Length (0-2)
  • Grammar (0-2)
  • Vocabulary (0-2)
  • Spelling (0-2)

Structure

Structure Verbs Alternatives
The speaker was discussingâ€¦ described
He mentionedâ€¦ highlighted
He talked aboutâ€¦ thought
He discssedâ€¦ seemed
Concluding Sectence compared
He suggested that â€¦ believed
He concluded by sayingâ€¦ contrasted
â€¦etc

entry.title: ã€PTEã€‘How to write Academicaly in PTE
entry.content:
PTE æŠ€å·§ - 7 ways academic writing

  1. Use no more than 1 or 2 personal pronouns
  2. Use a range of active and passive sentences
  3. Use modal verbs
  4. Use more formal, more precise words
  5. Use the noun form instead of the verb form
  6. Avoid contractions
  7. Use adverbs to â€˜hedgeâ€™ your ideas

Use no more than 1 or 2 personal pronouns

Personal pronouns: I, my, meâ€¦

Avoid personal pronouns where possible:
This essay will discuss three reasons whyâ€¦

NOTE: Using I or me once or twice is fine!

Use a range of active and passive sentences

Uses a mix of active and passive sentences.

Active: Governments should prohibit smoking in all outdoor areas.

Passive: Smoking should be prohibited in all outdoor areas.

Use modal verbs

Use might, could and wouldâ€¦

Example: Banning smoking in outdoor areas might deter people from smoking altogether.

Use more formal, more precise words

Uses less common but more precise words: Restricting smoking wouldâ€¦

Uses common words and phrasal verbs: Cutting back smoking willâ€¦

Use the noun form instead of the verb form

Noun Form: The prohibition of cigarettes would lead to a much healthier society.

Verb Form: If the government prohibited cigarettes, it would lead to a much healtier society.

Noun Form Verb Form
demonstration demonstrate
complaint complain
request ask
requirement need
recommondation recommond
suggestion suggest
invitation invit
development develop
wastage waste

Avoid contractions

Instead of writing â€œItâ€™dâ€ write â€œIt wouldâ€

Avoid contractions Use contractions
It is Itâ€™s
They are Theyâ€™re
Would not Wouldnâ€™t

Use adverbs to â€˜hedgeâ€™ your ideas

Uses adverbs to â€˜hedgeâ€™ language such as:

  • Probably
  • Possibly
  • Seemingly
  • Apparently
  • Arguably
  • Perhaps
  • Maybe
  • Presumably
  • Conceivably

Example: Banning smoking would probablyâ€¦

Uses informal adverbs to make language â€˜friendlierâ€™ such as:

  • very
  • really
  • pretty

Example: It was really funâ€¦

entry.content:
PTE å­¸ç¿’ç­†è¨˜ - WFD

Facts

  • Number: 3-4 tasks
  • Scoring: Listening and Writing

Scoring

Donâ€™t MISSPELL, LEAVE OUT and REPLACE words
